title: We’d lost our jobs, our home and cancer almost killed me...then we won £1million
text:

As Desiree and Wayne Home sit by their riverside house they watch the boats, listen to the birdsong... and reflect on a £1million Lotto win that saved them from the pit of despair.

Back in 2014, they were at “rock bottom”.

Desiree had learned she had bowel cancer in 2008 on her 50th birthday and was suffering multiple health problems.

They had both lost their jobs and been forced to sell their house and move into a mobile home. It only allowed residents over 47 so their teen daughter was living with her sister. Even their horses had to go.

Desiree says: “It was a nightmare – we lost everything, our health, house, horses, everything. It was such a hard time for the whole family.”

(Image: Tommy Reynolds Photography)

But at their lowest ebb, their luck changed when they won £1million with a Lucky Dip on EuroMillions.

Desiree says: “It was just amazing. I describe my life in a graph – a line rising upward for a long time, suddenly plummeting, and then going back through the roof. That’s what it felt like.”

Desiree and Wayne, both 61, met while they were in the Navy, based at Faslane on the Clyde. She was a Wren and Wayne was a submariner and they married in 1980 and built a good life together.

They had three children and bought a house in Tunbridge Wells, Kent.

Desiree says: “We really did think we would be there forever. It was a five-bedroom, 1930s semi with extensions, an attic conversion, en-suite bathrooms, a conservatory, a kitchen breakfast room, a downstairs shower room, garden, garage, dining room and study, the lot.”

But then, in February 2008, Desiree was diagnosed with bowel cancer.

She says: “Before I got cancer we really felt we had made it.

"We had worked hard all our adult lives and we had a beautiful home and a comfortable life.”

But the cancer treatment was so horrific it left her with PTSD.

She “kicked the bucket” on the operating table and was revived, only to suffer respiratory failure again 24 hours later.

She spent 11 days in intensive care.

(Image: Tommy Reynolds Photography)

During chemotherapy she developed cauda aquina syndrome, a spinal injury which could have left her paralysed.

She says: “I was lucky, they caught me in time. I have nerve damage, but I can walk. I had to have an implant to control my bowel and bladder, but for all intents and purposes I am pretty normal now.

“But I did suffer PTSD as a result of everything. Then there is our youngest daughter, only 16, doing her GCSEs, and having to take on a lot of responsibility and worry as her mum gets ill.”

Things got worse when Wayne, by then an IT project manager, became unemployed and Desiree lost her job too.

She says: “We couldn’t pay our bills, we had repossession looming, we had bailiffs turning up on the doorstep, debt letters coming through the post.

"Creditors standing on the doorstep pricing up our cars, you name it, it was a nightmare.

“Some friends stepped in and gave us a loan to be paid back as and when and just enough money to pay the mortgage for three months so we could sell the house ourselves and not allow bailiffs to do it.

“A friend took our horses because we couldn’t feed them.”

In 2013, they sold the house, paid off the mortgage and most of their debts and bought a mobile home in East Farleigh, Kent.

(Image: PA)

Desiree says: “I remember saying to the children before we moved out, ‘Make the most of this, this is as good as it’ll ever get for us in terms of homes’.

“I cried all the way from our old house to the mobile home. I didn’t want to give up our house or the lifestyle, but we had to move on, pay our debts, and go forward with our lives.”

In July 2014, their luck finally changed.

Desiree says: “Twice a week, Wayne bought a Lucky Dip. When we realised we had won, I went into shock.

“He only told me we had won half a million over the phone as he didn’t want me to be too shocked. I only found out we had won a million later that night.”

One of the first things they did was repay the friend’s loan and take her out to the Savoy to celebrate.

They have since given £300,000 to friends and charities, and bought a new home, a renovated pumping station with moorings on the riverside on the mobile home park, near their old place.

They make a small income from renting out the moorings and Desiree went back to work part-time as a receptionist and Wayne as a delivery driver.

Desiree says: “We wake each day to birdsong and we watch the boats wind their way up the river – a view we’ll never tire of. This corner of Kent has bought us luck, health and happiness.

“We feel so lucky and happy to have been given the chance to get our lives back on track.”
description: EXCLUSIVE: From rock bottom to EuroMillions success, the Homes' family fortunes really turned around
